content.description:
Large dark brown dyke that slants slightly right as it ascends the west face of Hardly Rock (1992 Vogel), the long wall to the right of the trail that has

Saltimbanco

on its backside.  This obvious dyke can be seen from the left end of No Falls Wall.  This route is listed in Bartlett's Central JT book, in its Supplement pages in the back.  Hardly Rock is fairly nondescript, with only two documented okay routes.  Makes enough sense to group each of those routes with their nearest more recognizable walls, what the book seems to favor.  Unless people object, lawyer up, and litigate for Hardly Rock.

Cave start up ledges as for R.D. Memorial but continue up the cave to reach the big overhead dangling columns (less choss to deal with for those with long limps), turn the roof that the underside of those columns make, then follow cracks up past a bush to a grainy topout.  There's a hefty Hersey Kiss shaped boulder sitting near the top that one has to step on in order to reach up to top out.  Felt heavy and solid, did not feel it budge, but as always, best not to crank outward to risk prying that off.
content.protection: Gear anchor with medium to big cams.
content.location: 2nd route from the left, on the left side of the central hollow area. Walkoff.

climbs.name: R.D. Memorial
climbs.fa: Alan Bartlett, Brandt Allen, Lisa Christie, 5/1990

content.description: Start up the easy big ledge on the left side of the giant prominent roof.  Pull up and left onto another ledge to turn out of the left side of that big roof to reach cracks that go up and slightly left to the top.  Interesting thought provoking sequence up near the finish.
content.protection: Single cams to 3" with medium doubles, gear anchor.
content.location: Leftmost documented crack route on the north-facing No Falls Wall.  Walkoff.

content.description: Up a left-slanting faint seam that improves to a more proper thin crack to get to the middle of the formation's high prominent roof.  Work past a downpoint flat block to reach a slightly right-slanting short seam to go up and over the roof to the top.
content.location: Center of the big prominent high roof.

content.description: Namesake route that starts up a steep face with a few low edges for feet and then a good stretch of scratching at barren rock with minimal features.  Lots of looseness and chossy bits still, with some hollow features just before reaching the midway slopey ledge, as in the bottom might continue to get harder as it cleans up.  Then pull the big fun roof via many helpful features that the bottom had chosen to lack.  Bottom and top halves are completely different in character.  Worth the raw tips and stress to get to crank on the easier big roof, which felt about solid 5.10. Bartlett's Central JT book rates the route 5.10d R/X with a 5.11a penciled in at the bottom slab in its topo diagram.
content.location: Right side of the center big wide roof.  This is the second rightmost route on the wall.

content.description: Right-slanting crack leads up to a slopey ledge, then up a steep crack that splits a dark brown face.  Rated 5.8 in Bartlett's Central JT book, but felt deserving of the extra plus (or two).  Walk off via easy scramble down and to climber's left to brush past trees, then cut back to the top of the starting pit.
content.location: This and Groover McTuber are located on the south-facing backside of No Falls Wall, on its inside left end.  Requires scrambling past some slopey ledges and tunneling into a cave.  This is the right side one of the two adjacent routes.  Both start on a boulder ledge inside a pit, and are located left of a prominent bulbous roof at the center of this south face.  That bulbous roof is visible from the trail.

content.description: This is the leftmost route on the south face that ascends a "deceptively easy-appearing" vertical groove.  Some loose bits detract.  Interesting body positions and moves.  Walk off via easy scramble down and to climber's left to brush past trees, then cut back to the top of the starting pit.
content.protection: Standard rack, gear anchor with long extension.
content.location: This and Hand Lotion are located on the south-facing backside of No Falls Wall, on its inside left end.  Requires scrambling past some slopey ledges and tunneling into a cave.  This is the left side one of the two adjacent routes.  Both start on a boulder ledge inside a pit, and are located left of a prominent bulbous roof at the center of this south face.

content.description: Funky starting moves up the obvious left-slanting crack with lichen blotches to the side.  Pull up helpful big juggy ledges near the middle and on to the top.
content.location: Rightmost documented crack route on the wall.
